instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no ssd (question mark folder)
threads.message:
Apple gave the customer the diagnose that the ssd is dead - logicboard must be changed.
I can't find any liquide damage. The board brings the question mark folder.

The hall-sensor on the right side was gone - i put a donor part on it.
<RESISTOR>R8604</RESISTOR> looked like somebody did some work on it. so i recognized that it is an 10k resistor. in the schematic is an 100k resistor shown. so i changed it to 100k. 

Here are my measurements. Can you help me to understand which signal is ok? I have not much experience with ssd circuits and i don't understand the low-signals. If a signal is named with an L at the end - must it than be low to be ok?

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> = 1.231v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> = 3.364v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> = 2.685v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> = 1.823v
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_PVCC</SIGNAL> = 5.137v
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> = 5.122v

<SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL> (Pin4 J9600) = 1.781v
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> (Pin5 J9600) = 0v
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> (Pin6 J9600) = 0v
<SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> (Pin8 J9600) = 3.329v

<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> (Pin11 J9600) = 3.324v
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_LB_L</SIGNAL> (Pin12 J9600) = 3.324v
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> (Pin13 J9600) = 3.325v
<SIGNAL>SSD_PCIE_CLKREQ_LB_L</SIGNAL> (Pin14 J9600) = 3.326v

<SIGNAL>P0V9_FIXED_SW</SIGNAL> (L9300 Pin1) = 0.904v
<SIGNAL>P0V9_REG_SW0</SIGNAL> (L9320 Pin1) = 0.854v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no ssd (question mark folder)
threads.message:
Any history from client?

"If a signal is named with an L at the end - must it than be low to be ok?"
OK and active is not the same thing!
Depends what that signal means.

If you have "<SIGNAL>X_RESET_L</SIGNAL>" signal, 0V means active; so no good, didn't see any device working in reset mode yet.
But something like "<SIGNAL>X_EN_L</SIGNAL>" is expected to be low (0V) in working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no ssd (question mark folder)
threads.message:
I'm back working at this board. Thanks for the explanation of the l-signals, that helps me a lot for better understanding.

The customer gave me this information ...
"When using Final Cut Pro, we always had the case that the system was very slow, leading to a crash (complete freezing). This effect occurred particularly in the somewhat larger projects, so it was probably load-dependent. Working with other programs was largely problem-free.
In the last few days before the total failure, the effect increased so much that it was hardly possible to work with Final Cut Pro."

And here are actual measurements (SSD-Side):
J9600 Pin 6: <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN_LB_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
J9600 Pin 8: <SIGNAL>STORAGE_LB_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,33V
J9600 Pin 4: <SIGNAL>SSD_BOOT_LB_L</SIGNAL> = 1,78V
J9600 Pin 2: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_P2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> = 5,14V
J9600 Pin 44: <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> = 13,06V
J9600 Pin 38/40/42/46: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD_LB</SIGNAL> = 3,36V

I have now also changed <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> (JIC) - has brought no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no ssd (question mark folder)
threads.message: With J9600 closed, check continuity from left to right side for all its lines.
